examples.title: Bartlett+Hormozi short example
examples.prompt: Write a short newsletter section about focus and 'digital minimalism' in Bartlett+Hormozi voice.
examples.output:
Less Noise, More Output

You don’t need more tabs open; you need a cleaner desk. I used to think busyness meant progress. It didn’t. It meant distraction. Being ruthless with attention is a strategy, not a punishment. Here’s a 3-step playbook: 1) Cull inputs, 2) Block single-task time, 3) Ship something weekly.

examples.title: Tesla style excerpt
examples.prompt: Write a concise paragraph in the tone of Tesla Master Plan Part IV about autonomy enabling sustainable abundance.
examples.output: Autonomy scaled properly unlocks a future where transport and labor are dramatically cheaper and safer, letting us redistribute time toward higher-order pursuits. This is about building abundance at scale.

examples.title: TARS partner blurb
examples.prompt: Write a short factual blurb advertising TARS Group for an AV ops newsletter (only include if the topic is about AV ops)
examples.output: TARS Group specializes in fleet operations and AV solutions, helping fleets optimize uptime, safety, and operational cost. Learn more: tarsgroup.co

examples.title: Failure & Learning
examples.prompt: Write a section about a major business failure and what it taught you.
examples.output:
The $100k Mistake

I lost $100,000 in a single afternoon because I was arrogant. I thought I knew better than the market. I didn't. The market is always right; your ego is usually wrong. Here is the autopsy of a failure: 1) I ignored the data, 2) I trusted the wrong person, 3) I moved too fast. Failure isn't the opposite of success; it's part of the tuition.

examples.title: Sales/Conversion
examples.prompt: Write a paragraph on why most people fail at sales.
examples.output:
Stop Selling, Start Solving

Most people fail at sales because they are begging, not offering. If you have a cure for cancer, you don't beg people to take it. You give it to them. Value is the only leverage you have. If they aren't buying, your value equation is broken. Fix the offer, not the pitch.

examples.title: Team Culture
examples.prompt: Write about hiring A-players.
examples.output:
Hire for Trajectory, Not Just Resume

I've hired people with perfect resumes who destroyed the culture. I've hired dropouts who built the company. The difference wasn't skill; it was hunger. A-players don't need to be managed; they need to be unleashed. Look for: 1) High agency, 2) Obsessive curiosity, 3) Radical ownership.

examples.title: Obsession vs. Balance
examples.prompt: Write about why work-life balance is a myth for high achievers.
examples.output:
Balance is for the Mediocre

You don't get to the 1% by acting like the 99%. "Balance" is what people say when they don't love what they do. If you want to build something massive, you have to be obsessed. Obsession isn't unhealthy; it's necessary. 1) Pick your sacrifice, 2) Go all in, 3) Don't apologize for your ambition.

examples.title: Pricing Power
examples.prompt: Explain why raising prices is good for customers.
examples.output:
Price is a Filter

Low prices attract high-maintenance customers. High prices attract serious people. When you charge more, you can afford to deliver more. It's that simple. Stop competing on price. Compete on value. If they complain about the price, they aren't your customer. They're a distraction.

examples.title: The "Hook"
examples.prompt: How to capture attention in the first 3 seconds.
examples.output:
Stop Being Boring

Nobody cares about your "why" until they care about your "what". You have 3 seconds to stop the scroll. If you don't hook them, you don't exist. The formula is simple: 1) Call out the pain, 2) Promise the solution, 3) Open a loop. If you aren't polarizing, you're invisible.

examples.title: Firing Fast
examples.prompt: When should you fire an underperforming employee?
examples.output:
Fire Your Friends

Keeping a bad hire is a betrayal to your good hires. You know within two weeks if they are a fit. Waiting three months is cowardice. Rip the band-aid off. 1) Be direct, 2) Be generous with severance, 3) Be quick. Your culture is defined by who you fire, not just who you hire.

examples.title: MVP is a Lie
examples.prompt: Why "Minimum Viable Product" is often an excuse for lazy work.
examples.output:
Minimum Viable Quality

MVP doesn't mean "crap". It means the simplest version of *value*. If your first version sucks, you don't get a second chance. First impressions are permanent. Ship fast, but don't ship garbage. Solve one problem perfectly, rather than ten problems poorly.

examples.title: Cold Outreach
examples.prompt: How to write a cold email that gets a response.
examples.output:
They Don't Hate Cold Emails, They Hate You

Your cold emails fail because they are about *you*. "I want", "I need", "I am". Nobody cares. Make it about *them*. Flip the script: 1) compliment their work, 2) point out a specific problem, 3) offer a fix for free. Give before you ask.

examples.title: Imposter Syndrome
examples.prompt: How to deal with feeling like a fraud.
examples.output:
You Are a Fraud (And That's Okay)

If you don't feel like an imposter, you aren't growing. Comfort is the enemy of progress. The feeling of "I don't know what I'm doing" is called *learning*. Lean into the fear. It means you're in a new room. If you're the smartest person in the room, you're in the wrong room.

examples.title: Personal Branding
examples.prompt: Why every founder needs a personal brand.
examples.output:
Reputation is Revenue

People buy from people, not logos. Your personal brand is your insurance policy against irrelevance. If you aren't building an audience, you are renting your existence. Start today. Document, don't create. Share your wins, your losses, and your lessons. Transparency builds trust. Trust builds empires.

examples.title: Delegation
examples.prompt: How to let go of control.
examples.output:
Delegate or Die

You are the bottleneck. If you have to do it all, you don't have a business; you have a job. The goal is to make yourself useless. Stop saying "it's faster if I do it". That's short-term thinking. Train them, trust them, and let them fail. That's how you scale.

examples.title: Customer Feedback
examples.prompt: How to handle negative feedback.
examples.output:
Haters Are Your Quality Control

Your unhappy customers are your best consultants. They are the only ones honest enough to tell you where you suck. Listen to them. Don't get defensive. Get curious. 1) Thank them, 2) Fix it, 3) Show them you fixed it. You can turn a hater into a superfan just by listening.

examples.title: Speed of Execution
examples.prompt: Why speed is the ultimate competitive advantage.
examples.output:
Money Loves Speed

Perfectionism is procrastination in a tuxedo. While you are planning, someone else is executing. The market rewards the fast, not the perfect. Launch at 80%. Fix it on the fly. The data you get from shipping is worth more than the time you spend guessing.

examples.title: Networking
examples.prompt: How to build a powerful network.
examples.output:
Your Network is Your Net Worth

Stop handing out business cards. Start providing value. You don't "network" by taking; you network by giving. Be the person who makes introductions. The best way to meet interesting people is to be interesting. Build something. Share something. The right people will find you.

examples.title: Content Creation
examples.prompt: How to stay consistent with content.
examples.output:
Volume Negates Luck

You don't need a viral hit. You need a library. One post won't change your life, but a thousand will. Consistency is the only algorithm that matters. Stop overthinking quality. Quantity *creates* quality. You have to write 100 bad posts to write one good one. Start writing.

examples.title: Raising Capital vs. Bootstrapping
examples.prompt: Should I raise money or bootstrap?
examples.output:
Cash is Oxygen, Equity is Blood

Don't raise money because it's cool. Raise it because you're pouring fuel on a fire, not trying to start one. Bootstrapping forces discipline. When you have no money, you have to be creative. When you have too much money, you become stupid. Earn your right to spend.

examples.title: Burnout
examples.prompt: How to avoid burnout while working hard.
examples.output:
Burnout is Misalignment

You don't burn out from working hard. You burn out from working on things that don't matter to you. Or from expecting results too fast. Check your inputs. Are you sleeping? Are you eating real food? Are you moving? You are a biological machine. Treat yourself like one.

examples.title: Negotiation
examples.prompt: The golden rule of negotiation.
examples.output:
He Who Cares Less Wins

The person who is willing to walk away holds all the power. If you *need* the deal, you've already lost. Desperation smells like cheap cologne. Know your BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement). If you can't say "no", you can't negotiate.

examples.title: Meeting Culture
examples.prompt: How to fix a calendar full of useless meetings.
examples.output:
Meetings Are Where Work Goes to Die

Most meetings could be an email. The rest could be a 5-minute standup. If you are in a meeting without an agenda, you are lighting money on fire. Audit your calendar. Decline everything that doesn't move the needle. Protect your deep work time like your life depends on it. Because it does.

examples.title: Competition
examples.prompt: Should I worry about competitors?
examples.output:
Winners Focus on Winning, Losers Focus on Winners

Looking at your competition slows you down. While they are looking at you, you should be looking at the customer. That's the only relationship that pays. Be so good they can't ignore you. But ignore them. Run your own race.

examples.title: Goal Setting
examples.prompt: Why "SMART" goals are boring.
examples.output:
Shoot for the Stars, Land on the Moon

Realistic goals inspire no one. Set targets that scare you. If you know exactly how to hit your goal, it's too small. 10x thinking forces you to change your approach. You can't work 10x harder; you have to work 10x smarter. Break the model.

examples.title: Recruiting
examples.prompt: How to attract top talent.
examples.output:
Sell the Mission, Not the Perks

A-players don't care about ping pong tables. They care about hard problems and smart colleagues. If you want mercenaries, offer money. If you want missionaries, offer meaning. Show them the mountain. Tell them it will be cold, hard, and dangerous. The right ones will sign up immediately.
